reportSummary.summary: This watershed management plan, focused on the Pickwick Reservoir Watersheds in northeast Mississippi, outlines strategies to address water quality impairments in the Bear, Yellow, and Indian Creek watersheds. The plan emphasizes reduction of sediment and nutrient loads, implementation of BMPs, and public outreach, with the goal of restoring listed streams and protecting public and ecological health across the region.
reportSummary.planTitle: Pickwick Reservoir Watersheds (MS-06030005 and MS-0603006, in part) Watershed Management Plan
organizations: Tishomingo County Soil and Water Conservation District
Alcorn County Soil and Water Conservation District
Mississippi Department of Wildlife, Fisheries and Parks
Mississippi Soil and Water Conservation Commission
Prentiss County Soil and Water Conservation District
reportSummary.geographicRegion: Tishomingo County, Mississippi (plus portions of adjacent counties and Alabama)

goals.description: Develop a mechanism for removing Caney, Bear, Cripple Deer, and Little Cripple Deer Creeks and Holly Branch from MDEQ’s list of impaired waters.
goals.sourceExcerpt: The long-term goal of those creating the Pickwick Reservoir watershed plan is to develop a mechanism for removing Caney, Bear, Cripple Deer, and Little Cripple Deer Creeks and Holly Branch from MDEQ’s list of impaired waters...

goals.description: Establish a locally-led watershed team to address water quality issues.
goals.schedule: First three years of the project
goals.sourceExcerpt: Short-term goals to be achieved during the first three years of this project will include: • Establishment of a locally-led watershed team to address water quality issues.

goals.description: Completion of a Source Water Protection Plan for the Short Coleman Water Association.
goals.schedule: First three years of the project
goals.sourceExcerpt: • Completion of a Source Water Protection Plan for the Short Coleman Water Association.

goals.description: Documentation of baseline conditions for sediment, nitrogen and phosphorus loading in all listed stream segments.
goals.schedule: First three years of the project
goals.sourceExcerpt: • Documentation of baseline conditions for sediment, nitrogen and phosphorus loading in all listed stream segments.

goals.description: Reduce sediment, nitrogen, and phosphorus loads in listed streams.
goals.schedule: First three years of the project (ongoing)
goals.sourceExcerpt: • Reduction in sediment, nitrogen and phosphorus loads.*

goals.description: Improve water quality in Caney and Bear Creeks so at least 40% of the stream lengths can be removed from the 303(d) list by 2015.
goals.sourceExcerpt: • Improve water quality in Caney and Bear Creeks so that at least 40% of the stream lengths can be removed from the 303(d) list of impaired water bodies by 2015.

goals.description: Restore at least 20 acres of riparian buffer in the Bear and Yellow Creek Watersheds.
goals.schedule: First three years of the project
goals.sourceExcerpt: • Restoration of at least 20 acres of riparian buffer in the Bear and Yellow Creek Watersheds.

goals.description: Stabilize at least 1,500 feet of severely eroding stream bank in the Bear and Yellow Creek Watersheds.
goals.schedule: First three years of the project
goals.sourceExcerpt: • Stabilization of at least 1500 feet of severely eroding stream bank in the Bear and Yellow Creek Watersheds.

bmps.name: Animal Exclusion
bmps.description: Install fencing to prevent animal access to stream banks; plant excluded lands in hardwood vegetation and install alternate water systems if needed.
bmps.sourceExcerpt: Cost-share assistance will be available to land owners who install fencing to prevent animal access to stream banks in listed portions of Bear, Cripple Deer and Little Cripple Deer Creeks, Holly Branch and all areas in the Yellow Creek watershed.

bmps.name: Pasture Restoration
bmps.description: Restore overgrazed or poorly conditioned pastures and convert to native warm-season grasses where possible.
bmps.sourceExcerpt: Cost-share assistance will be available to land owners who wish to restore overgrazed pastures or pastures which have been identified as being in poor condition.

bmps.name: Rotational Grazing
bmps.description: Install fencing to divide pastures and implement rotational grazing.
bmps.sourceExcerpt: Cost-share assistance will be available to land owners who install fencing to divide pastures so that rotational grazing can be used to prevent overgrazing and pasture degradation.

bmps.name: Grade Stabilization
bmps.description: Construct stabilization structures to reduce erosion in gullies, ditches and other drainages.
bmps.sourceExcerpt: Cost share assistance will be available to land owners to construct stabilization structures to reduce erosion in gullies, ditches and other drainages.

bmps.name: Sediment Basin
bmps.description: Construct settling basins, retention ponds or similar structures to reduce sediment run-off from agricultural lands.
bmps.sourceExcerpt: Cost share assistance will be available to land owners to construct settling basins, retention ponds or similar structures to reduce sediment run-off from agricultural lands.

bmps.name: Harvest Planning
bmps.description: Develop a harvest plan with BMPs for logging roads, landings, and stream crossings; required for cost-share assistance after timber harvest activities.
bmps.sourceExcerpt: Land owners wishing to receive funding assistance through this project will work with the Mississippi Forestry Commission to develop a harvest plan for their land.

bmps.name: Logging Road Revegetation
bmps.description: Sow grasses along logging roads immediately after harvest; includes grading as needed for runoff control.
bmps.sourceExcerpt: Cost-share assistance will be available to sow grasses along logging roads immediately after harvest is complete.

bmps.name: Landing Restoration
bmps.description: Sow grasses throughout logging landing areas used during operations.
bmps.sourceExcerpt: Cost-share assistance will be available to sow grasses throughout areas used to stage equipment and activities during logging operations.

bmps.name: Stream Crossing Restoration
bmps.description: Grade and reforest any areas where stream crossings were required during harvest activities, stabilize stream banks as needed.
bmps.sourceExcerpt: Cost-share assistance will be available to grade and reforest any areas where stream crossings were required during harvest activities.

bmps.name: Riparian Buffer Restoration
bmps.description: Restore at least 20 acres of riparian buffer in the Bear and Yellow Creek Watersheds.
bmps.schedule: First three years of the project
bmps.sourceExcerpt: • Restoration of at least 20 acres of riparian buffer in the Bear and Yellow Creek Watersheds.

bmps.name: Stream Bank Stabilization
bmps.description: Stabilize at least 1,500 feet of severely eroding stream bank in the Bear and Yellow Creek Watersheds.
bmps.schedule: First three years of the project
bmps.sourceExcerpt: • Stabilization of at least 1500 feet of severely eroding stream bank in the Bear and Yellow Creek Watersheds.

implementation.sourceExcerpt: Develop Source Water Assessment for Short Coleman Water Association June 2008 June 2009 TVA

implementation.description: Develop Source Water Protection Plan for Short Coleman Water Association.
implementation.sourceExcerpt: Develop Source Water Protection Plan for Short Coleman Water Association July 2009 March 2010 MDEQ, EPA, TVA

implementation.sourceExcerpt: Conduct educational events for public awareness and participation September 2008 End of project TVA, EPA

implementation.sourceExcerpt: Provide regular project updates to partners, local residents, government officials and interested parties June 2008 End of project All partners

implementation.description: Establish BMPs on lands throughout the watershed to reduce pollution loading.
implementation.sourceExcerpt: Establish BMPs on lands throughout the watershed to reduce pollution loading June 2008 End of project SWCD, MFC

implementation.description: Conduct septic system education events and assist home-owners with failing septic systems.
implementation.sourceExcerpt: Conduct septic system education events and assist home-owners with failing septic systems June 2008 End of project TVA, EPA

implementation.sourceExcerpt: Conduct water quality protection events with reservoir user groups to increase awareness for source water protection October 2008 End of project TVA

implementation.description: Conduct regular public meetings to provide updates/information.
implementation.sourceExcerpt: Conduct regular public meetings to provide updates/information June 2008 End of project All partners
Monitor chemical status September 2008 December 2011 TVA, MDEQ
Monitor biological status January 2008 December 2013 TVA, MDEQ

monitoring.method: MDEQ standard protocols or TVA Level II sampling protocol
monitoring.frequency: Twice per 5-year interval (beginning of project, year 3, year 5)
locations: Little Yellow Creek at Mississippi Highway 365
Cripple Deer Creek at County Road 157
Cripple Deer Creek at the Alabama/Mississippi state line
monitoring.sourceExcerpt: Macroinvertebrate data will be collected twice during each five year interval. Initial data will be collected at the beginning of the project (2008). Additional data will be collected after three years (2011) and again after two more years (2013).
Fish data will be collected every five years. Initial data will be collected at the beginning of the project (2008) and additional data will be collected in five years (2013).

monitoring.method: Monthly in situ/lab sampling, QA/QC per MDEQ/TVA standards
locations: Little Yellow Creek at Mississippi Highway 365
Bear Creek at Natchez Trace Parkway
Cripple Deer Creek at Mississippi Highway 25
Cripple Deer Creek at County Road 157
Cripple Deer Creek at the Alabama/Mississippi state line
Little Cripple Deer Creek at County Road 957
monitoring.sourceExcerpt: Chemical monitoring during this project will consist of multiple parameters sampled on a monthly basis throughout the project period... Measurements of total suspended solids (TSS)... will be used to tract reductions in sediment loading in these streams.

monitoring.method: Monthly sampling; devices with temperature, pH, conductivity
monitoring.frequency: Monthly; before 10:00 a.m. during summer in Yellow Creek watershed (May-September)
monitoring.sourceExcerpt: Measurements of dissolved oxygen (DO) and biological oxygen demand (BOD) will be used to tract conditions. Since nutrient loading in a stream greatly affects conditions leading to low DO impairment...

outreach.description: Conduct public meetings during initial phases to increase awareness of local citizens and introduce project plans.
outreach.sourceExcerpt: Public Meetings – Meetings will be conducted during the initial phases of this project to increase awareness of local citizens concerning current issues in the watersheds and to introduce project plans to potential partners.

outreach.description: Presentations to stakeholder groups (Cattlemen’s Association, Forestry Association, Economic Development agencies) to introduce project and provide updates.
outreach.sourceExcerpt: Stakeholder Presentations – Periodically, partners will meet with local stakeholder groups... to introduce this project to members and keep them up-to-date with project activities.

outreach.description: Presentations and written reports to local, state, and federal agencies to provide project summaries and results.
outreach.sourceExcerpt: Government Briefings – As needed, presentations will be made to local, state and federal agencies to provide project summaries and present results.

outreach.description: Workshops for watershed residents (e.g., septic system maintenance, clean boating, riparian buffers, forestry, Envirothon, Secchi Day).
outreach.sourceExcerpt: Activity Workshops – As needed, workshops will be held to distribute information and ideas to watershed residents concerning various aspects of this project.

outreach.description: Tours given to interested land owners, potential partners, and agencies highlighting BMP project successes.
outreach.sourceExcerpt: Project Tours – As BMP projects are implemented, tours will be given to interested land owners, potential partners and various agencies to increase awareness of project activities and to highlight project successes.

outreach.description: Hands-on educational events with area schools and organizations to increase awareness of water quality issues.
outreach.sourceExcerpt: Watershed Education Events – Partners will work with area schools and organizations to provide hands-on educational events to increase awareness of water quality issues...

outreach.description: Regular updates to partners, local residents, government officials, and interested parties.
outreach.sourceExcerpt: Provide regular project updates to partners, local residents, government officials and interested parties June 2008 End of project All partners

geographicAreas.sourceExcerpt: Pickwick Reservoir Watersheds (MS-06030005 and MS-0603006, in part)
Pickwick Reservoir Watersheds (MS-06030005 and MS-0603006, in part)
Yellow Creek enters Pickwick Reservoir at TRM 215 near the Tennessee-Mississippi state line.
Bear Creek enters Pickwick Reservoir at TRM 225 near the Mississippi-Alabama state line.
Indian Creek enters Pickwick Reservoir at TRM 220. Its headwaters drain through the city of Iuka.
